      Former Employee, more than 3 years

      PNC as a Whole

      Aug 18, 2021 - Anonymous Employee in Washington, DC
      Recommend
      CEO Approval
      Business Outlook

      Pros

      I was able to do some financial planning for the future such as creating a retirement plan and buying some shares at a discounted rate until I resigned then they make you pay it back by deducting it from your shares. This was a great opportunity for me to see what types of jobs I never want again my regret is that I didn’t resign sooner. I’m grateful to have worked in both the branches and corporate.

      Cons

      Branch roles pay you minimum wage and claim they can’t give you more than what they offer because they want you to make up the difference with incentives, but depending on which locations you’re working at it’s not possible especially because incentives are capped. You can get fired for they slightest things. Most of mangers and supervisors that I worked with while at the company have been a complete nightmare everyone seems to be treated like unwanted step kids and are talked to disrespectfully especially to get the desired results. While working here I’ve had a total of 11 or more managers and supervisors and have had only about 3 decent ones. Work life balance doesn’t exist for regular branch employee you are like a modern day slave especially because there is not loyalty to high performing employees, you will get fired in the branch a quicker than people steeling.

    4. 3.0

        ★★★★★
      • Senior Management
        ★★★★★
      Current Employee

      Strong safe honest financial institution with lack of direction

      Sep 23, 2021 - Treasury Management Officer in Charlotte, NC
      Recommend
      CEO Approval
      Business Outlook

      Pros

      Bank recognizes value of technology and ongoing training of employees. It is very focused on diversity and inclusion and offers a broad product suite to meet the needs of any business or individual. There's definitely a local community feel in this national big bank. Benefits are competitive and within the industry. PNC would certainly be a preferred employer.

      Cons

      There is a sense of lack of direction from leadership. This is evidenced by constant turnover from frontline team members all the way up through line of business leaders. Every new leader tries to reinvent the wheel with some new go-to-market approach that's just a different color wrapper if the same old thing. The constant retrain is exhausting, inefficient, and takes the focus off the customer. Also, with frontline turnover in excess of 50% annually, relationship building with customers is problematic. This may be normal for industry, but it's an issue. There is also a definite feel that it is often who you know and not your performance that opens doors to advancement. Sure, PNC plays the HR games of loading your resume internally for recruiting, having career development talks with your manager, and having a "plan." But at the end of the day managers want to hold on to top performers not promote them, and it's really who you know if you want upward mobility. Typical big corporate activity. Another challenge are the line of business silos creating lack of cooperation. Lots of lip service to being on the same team, but goals are sales oriented, not service and retention oriented, so reality is more of a fend for yourself and what have you sold lately. Branches are being converted to cashless sales centers as transaction volume migrates to online channels, which is fine, but it does highlight sales over service for the whole industry and it's true at PNC as well.

      Continue reading
